Sun of Faith - English: The Shakya youths jumped into their carts and wagons to get back to Kapilavastu
Manual - English: At the roof of a mansion, Gopā (sa mtsho ma) sees the Buddha. With the big toe of her one foot, she causes a hole on the roof. The Buddha, in a carriage, sees Gopā when the iron arrow breaks into pieces in his hand.  In a mansion, he takes Gopā as his bride.

Sun of Faith - English: and the oracle-priests again predicted: “If in these coming seven years Siddhartha does not renounce the secular way of life, he will become a universal monarch.”
One day, Gopa (Sa 'tsho ma), a pearl among women, daughter to *Shakya Ghantaghosha (Shakya dril bu sgra), was looking from her balcony at the road below.
The Bodhisattva noticed her standing thus. With his big toe he braked and brought his carriage to an abrupt halt.
The horses and coachman might well make strenuous efforts to keep the carriage in motion—the vehicle did not budge one whit.
Scene working notes: The Vinayavastu passage does not mention the "strenous efforts" of the horses and coachman but just says that the vehicle wouldn't budge: "shing rta mnan nas mi g.yo bar gyur pa"

Sun of Faith - English: Rapt in the sight of the young woman, the Bodhisattva crushed a lead arrow that he had in his hand to powder.
Gopa, on her side was also unable to take her eyes off the prince.
Her foot pressed so hard against the balcony floor that she left an imprint of it.
“Now here's a woman who would get along very well with the prince,” the people again murmured.
And the rumor reached King Shuddhodana,
who invited Gopa and her twenty thousand ladies in waiting to the palace so that she could be wedded to Siddhartha.
